captions.text:
CHRIS HARRIS: Couldn't get more
American if we tried--

Manhattan skyline and the two
muscle cars of the moment--
Camaro ZL1 and Mustang GT500.

Between them, they have
1,259 horsepower.

And yet they cost a lot less
than a 997 Turbo S.

So I've got two days
with these cars.

I want to drive them in New
York, because that's a fun
thing to do.

And then I want to drive
them on a circuit.

And then I want to reach
some conclusions
about the two of them.

As a European, I'm massively
excited.

Because they're so powerful,
and they
represent so much value.
Let's get it on.

So is this the worst place on
the planet to drive a car?
MALE SPEAKER: To drive?

CHRIS HARRIS: Could
be, couldn't it?

MALE SPEAKER: Yeah,
I think so.
CHRIS HARRIS: Could be.

Anyhow, at least I've
got a Camaro ZL1.

I suppose I'd better get that
straight first, haven't I?

Am I going to call it
a ZL1 or a Zed L1?

I suppose, being in America,
I ought to call it a ZL1.

Luckily and handily for these
purposes, General Motors has

decided to detune the
ZR1 Corvette engine
and put it in a Camaro.

And it's only got
588 horsepower.
Get that?
Detuned to 588.
566 foot-pounds of torque.

And I'm going to be able to
demonstrate about, oh, seven
of those, I would have thought,
where we're going now.
Initial thoughts, then?

It's not a difficult car
to drive slowly, this.

It's not a difficult
car at all.

Three petals, clutch is fine,
gearbox is light.

We forget that, don't we, that
if you had a car with this

much power 15 years ago--
actually, they didn't exist,

did they-- but a mega horsepower
car had awful

slackness in the gearshift,
and the whole transmission

moved around on rubber mounts
and it felt horrible.
This doesn't feel like that.
It's a little bit of slot.
But it's tight.
And it's easy to drive.
I like the cabin too.
This thing is $48,000 basic.

So it's kind of slightly
well-equipped 325i BMW money.
And you get 588 horsepower.

I don't have very good form
with New York City.

I've been here once before and
I got off the plane, had a

good afternoon, and then
the lights went off.
This was August, 2003--

I think it was-- when they
had the blackout.
I got stuck here for two days.

I spent $500 to sleep on some
stranger's floor one night.

So I don't have much
good history.

But I do find it a great place
to come on [INAUDIBLE].
And it's good for cars too.

You see some really interesting
cars, because

people just seem to use some
old, eclectic stuff and leave
it on the street side.

This morning I saw
a BMW E28 525e.
I was just cooing all over it.
People thought I was mad.

But it looked so incongruous and
cool next to all the other
new, modern cars.
Ah, look.
G63 or G55.

Are you allowed to drive a G55
if you've not got a Russian
passport and a cocaine habit?
[LAUGHTER]

MALE SPEAKER: Getting a lot of
looks around here, though, in
these two cars.
That's for sure.

CHRIS HARRIS: That's what it's
all about though, isn't it?

They are partly about being seen
and heard, aren't they?
They're pretty good at it too.

I'm at a red light and it's
clear road ahead of us.

So the temptation is to
make a lot of noise.

But I don't know, is that a bad
thing to do in New York?
What's it like in first gear?
[ENGINE SOUNDS]

CHRIS HARRIS: It's
quite quick.

I went a bit more
than 30 there.

MALE SPEAKER: What's the
speed limit here?

CHRIS HARRIS: It's a lovely
thing to tool around in.
I like it.
The seat is nice.

They've been quite
clever here.

Everything that you touch has
got sort of Alcantara on it.

So all the contact points--
there's a stumpy little gear

lever here which looks
like it was just
nicked from an M5 actually.

It feels great, because it's
all quite a soft touch.
I like this thing.

Strangely when I said I liked
it, everyone back at the Drive

office just went, [GROAN],
it's a Camaro.
I don't like them.
It's wrong.
They're all very pro-Mustang.

Of course, being a complete
foreigner, I don't really

understand the complexities and
the subtleties of the Ford
versus Chevrolet thing.

I just want to take them on
merit, really, and judge them.

This, to me, feels like
a nicely resolved car.

So I'm going to spend a bit of
time making sure that it

shifts gear well at low
speed, that the
engine's got usable torque.

It may have massive numbers,
but it's up to you how much
you use of it.

And that's all I'm going
to say about
driving the ZL1 slowly.

Because we need to go and do
some stupid stuff with it,
really, don't we?
So this is a Mustang GT500.

Its numbers are so
extraordinary, I'm not even
going to mention them now.

I'm just going to sort of settle
myself into the beast.

And then we'll discuss the
numbers in a minute.

Because they are,
frankly, [BLEEP]
ridiculous.

This is a bit brutal,
isn't it?
Jesus.
Talk about a short shift.

To quote the best motoring
journalist cliche of all, it's
like a rifle bolt.
[BLEEP]
me, that's fast.
It's got loads of grunt.

I feel like I'm sitting in
a Range Rover, though.

I'm too high relative to
the steering wheel.

If I was to get twirly in
oversteer, I could probably

shave my testicles with the
bottom of the wheel.

It's actually not the easiest
car to drive slowly, whereas

the ZL1 really does just feel
to me like any sort of three
pedal, American, fast car.
This is a bit more difficult.
The clutch bite point is high.

Because of this seat being in
the wrong position, my angle

of attack from my knee down to
the petals is a bit funny.

I'm sitting too high relative
to the wheel.

And of course there's
that power figure.
We'll come to it now.
671 horsepower.
Say that to yourself.

671 horsepower through,
effectively, a live axle.
It's just barking, isn't it?

Who was it who said, sort of
post-Lehman that Ford and GM

were going to have to sort their
shit out and stop making
muscle cars.

Well, a few years later,
we're at the 670
horsepower Mustang mark.

So someone called that
wrong, didn't they?
Torque--
631 foot-pounds.
It's a monster.

It's a much, much, more powerful
machine than that yob

yellow thing behind me, which
itself is crazy enough.
I love it.

And the price of these things--
they are $35 grand

cars if they were sold in the
UK at the same price as they
are over here.

So you could have the thick end
of 700 horsepower for the

price of a sort of mid-style,
three series BMW.

Isn't that something
to be celebrated?

When you get to that sort of
level, I don't really care

about the way they handle
or whether they're as
good as a BMW M3.

It makes no odds whatsoever,
does it?

Obviously, I'm a limey
tourist here today.
We've driven around New York.

And we've seen a few
bits and bobs.

But J.R. said, if there's one
place you want to go to, where
would it be?

Times Square, all that stuff--
not really very interested.

I like the Chrysler building,
but I've seen that before.

And I've been at the
Empire States.
And we're in cars.

But there was one place I wanted
to visit, and I've

always wanted to visit ever
since I first saw a little
program called The Sopranos.
I wanted to go to the Bing.

Who wouldn't want to
go to the Bing?

Not go into the Bing and use
its services, obviously,

because I don't need a happy
ending as we're speaking now.
But here we are-- the Bing.
[ENGINE REVVING]

CHRIS HARRIS: Boy do these
cars get some attention.
They look and sound the part.

And most of Manhattan appears
to adore them,
even the local police.

MALE SPEAKER 2: So that's
three pull-overs in
literally one hour.

And every time you've
gotten out of it.

CHRIS HARRIS: There's something
to be said for
mooching and posing in them.

Because they're not actually
that good on the open road.
I tell a lie.
That's unfair on the ZL.

The GT500 skips over bumps, the
power delivery is pretty

savage, and the exhaust
noise is grating.
The ZL is much more composed.

In fact, it's just a nicer
fast road car--
quieter and easier.

But do you buy muscle to
be easier and quieter?
I don't know.

Let's go to the track and wreck
some tires before we

even attempt to answer
that one.

OK, we're at Monticello Motor
Club now and finally have the

chance to use some of this
massive amount of horsepower.

We're in the ZL1 first, the
weakest by some margin.

How often do you say that of a
car that has 580 horsepower?

This is quite a heavy
brute though--
1,860 kilograms.

So I don't expect, given that
it's about 85 degrees outside,

to be able to pound around
for too long.

So let's go and do a couple
of laps and just
see how the car behaves.

And for me as a European, I have
to say, people like me

have quite a jaundiced view of
these American performance

cars-- too big, too heavy,
and not really on a
par with the Europeans.

But these are quite serious
performance cars.

They've got a lot
of performance.
Motor's great.

But it doesn't feel like
it's got 580 to me.

Maybe that's because
it is so heavy.

Brake pedal-- a little
bit blunt.

To me, feels like sort of M3
performance and a bit.

I've got the safety systems
on at the moment.

And it's really working
hard at the back axle.

We have got oversteer whenever
we want it, boys.
Bodes well for [INAUDIBLE].
Do you know what?

As a European, this does not
feel at all bad, this thing.
It's not the last word.
But it's pretty good.
It's really pretty good.

I have to say, initial
thoughts--

this car has hugely benefited
from having an
independent rear end.

It doesn't feel like the most
sophisticated rear end.
But it does feel--

well, I know it goes over
bumps in the middle of a

corner and doesn't get
spat sideways.

And the chassis is not being
completely overpowered by this

engine, not by a long
shot actually.

It feels like quite a nice
balanced package.
Yes.

Now we can let it move
around a bit.

But its advantage over the Ford
is it's got 305 section

rear tire-- so less power,
more mechanical grip.

It's quite a useful
recipe, isn't it?
I'm going full power here.
I can't make the thing drift.

A surprising, slightly strange
car we have here, Thomas.

I'm properly trying to back
it in, but it won't do it.

Maybe the ambient temperature
isn't helping the old girl.

Here's a good question
to ask yourself
on a Thursday afternoon.

What does 671 horsepower within
a body weighing 1,747

kilograms feel like when
it's transmitted to the
road via a live axle?
Welcome to the GT500.

I'm leaving all the systems
on to start with.
First thing's first.
This seat--
I'm sitting too high.

I've already got traction issues
and I've just used
about a third of throttle.

Yeah, this is going to be a
handful, this thing, isn't it?
What an engine.

So much more powerful than
the Camaro engine.

Yeah, this car is dominated
by its motor.

It's an engine looking
for a chassis.

I'm not convinced it's
found it in this
particular car, either.

Now we caught them-- but the
axle is absolutely having a
massive tantrum with itself.

God, it just feels so much
faster in a straight line.
Braking--
OK.

Has it got a spool diff
on it or something?
It feels like a drift car.

I think it's extraordinary,
absolutely extraordinary.

And anyone from my continent
that sniffs at it not being as

dignified as an M3 can saw it
off, because this is properly

exciting, this thing,
properly exciting.
The engine just keeps going.

And rarely has a car said to me,
as clearly and as loudly,

please turn the traction
control off.

Please turn the traction
control off.
This is a factory car--
670 horsepower.
It's not some tuner nonsense.
This comes with a warranty.
I do like it.
I do like it.
It's crude and it's--
but you know what?

For all that crudity, it's just
much more exciting and
much faster than the Camaro.

Where there's no bumps, the live
axle isn't as much of a
problem as you'd expect.

But when there are bumps,
it's not ideal.
There.

It's making me wait an eternity
to get on the gas.
It's so much fun though.

And it's the same price
as a loaded up 325i.

These are actually quite
different cars.

The Ford is lighter,
more powerful,
and generally crazier.

The Camaro is much
more rounded.

In as much as I could imagine
living with it every day the

way I could, say, an Audi RS
or an AMG Mercedes, how you

judge them clearly depends
on your Chevy or Ford
affiliation.

But once you've chosen your
tattoo, it actually comes down

to what you expect from
a modern muscle car.

Because I'm a limey not
regularly exposed to this

stuff, I wanted to rip my arms
off and scare my children.
And the ZL doesn't do that.
It's too good for that.

Despite giving away power and
weight, it was two seconds

faster around Monticello
in my hands.

But in the land of muscle,
bad is good.

And the GT500 is the
baddest of all.

Now how do I import one
to the UK again?

title: Ford Shelby GT500 v Chevrolet Camaro ZL1 : Street & Circuit - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.text: What does "live axle" mean?﻿
comments.author: therandomchannnel

comments.text:
Imagine that; the state of the art, better handling and race course faster 
Camaro is sneered at as a state SUBSIDIZED (&ONLY) 580hp  vehicle  compared 
to the factory warranted Mustang with , well, REAL horsepower.
BTW, is a car that was developed and succeeded from performance through 
sales during the same period that the production company borrowed and fully 
repaid all of its federal loans tainted in some way that detracts from its 
excellence?
...and doesn't Ford, GM as well as all of the firms offer warrantees?﻿
comments.author: Joe Heasley

comments.text: the u.s would be fucked if FORD  and GM & Dodge stop making car's like this﻿
comments.author: DJ JONES

comments.text: I hate both of them.﻿
comments.author: Steve Buscemi

comments.text:
THe new mustang using flat engine R350 and sounds best. I am ford guy 
mustang guy, who lives in europe and i had 3 fords, now i got bmw because 
of work. again i will buy another mustang but  zl1 rules to. But i rather 
have mustang. Love r350 mustang flat engine new technology :)﻿
comments.author: MakeSh00t

comments.text: 14:33 That seating position though..﻿
comments.author: Sam Baaj

comments.text:
People argue about which one is better as if they made and designed these 
cars!!! I love both but I just so happen to have a Camaro SS and I love 
it...but there are days I see a 2015 mustang gt and wish I had that...one 
day I'll have both in my garage!!!! One track one drag bam﻿
comments.author: Mikal Wright

comments.text:
+Mikal Wright You are speaking the truth, I have a 5.0 but was really close 
to getting an SS, If i had the money I would have gotten a 1LE, that thing 
is a monster on the track. Both are awesome cars!
comments.author: ImpendingDisaster26

comments.text: Both these cars look better than a BMW.﻿
comments.author: Kaz W

comments.text:
Top Gear please hire this man...

comments.author: Fromthefuture

comments.text: I am a ford guy but check out the Heallcat too Chris.﻿
comments.author: Gerwich Saint-Hilaire

comments.text:
wouldn't it be a little more even if you had an aftermarket mustang 
(gt500/roush whatever) vs an aftermarket (lingenfelter/Hennessy) camaro, 
but i can see why they do these two because the GT is still down with the 
SS. I love both cars though. I feel like ford should make a competitor 
similar to the corvette﻿
comments.author: Its a whiteboi

comments.text:
Too bad the shelby wasn't made for the track. They should've used the Boss 
302!﻿
comments.author: Izaak Minnick

comments.text: Well said.﻿
comments.author: Sam Johnson

comments.text: I really like new 2015 mustang and i would rather buy gt with automatic ﻿
comments.author: Ivan Bekish

comments.text: +Ivan Bekish automatic? really? Please stop.
comments.author: VirusTornado

comments.text: whats a cum arrow?﻿
comments.author: mmmmmm63

comments.text: The Mustang is like sex with no condom.﻿
comments.author: Kevin Lew

comments.text:
I'm a Ford guy and I think the guys in the white coats over in Dearborn 
have two things to talk about. First,the drive-line performance and 
selection in the Mustang is far superior to the Camaro. Second,they need to 
re-evaluate the chassis because the Camaro's is currently better than the 
Mustang's.﻿
comments.author: Durham Porsche

comments.text:
+Jimmy Hostetler Fair enough, I can't argue there. A newer GT would also be 
a lot more comfortable as a DD. Awesome! Incoming PM!!
comments.author: Nickolas Little

comments.text:
Well, I considered it.  This is going to be my daily driver though, If I 
got a Terminator I would keep it as a toy, and I don't have room for 
anymore toys in my garage!!  Plus they are a little pricey for the power 
they deliver.  A 99-01 with a supercharger would be cheaper and potentially 
deliver more power.  Lastly my current toy has about double terminator 
power.  Private message me I will send you some pics.
comments.author: Jimmy Hostetler

comments.text:
+Jimmy Hostetler Good lord I just got all tingly thinking about what a GT 
would be like with your list of mods. Shoot the Borla alone will make 
panties drop. You ever think about getting an '03 Termi?
comments.author: Nickolas Little

comments.text:
+Nickolas Little
 Yup! The Camaro is going to get a complete redesign, so if you don't like 
the current one the next one might suite you better!

I currently have... too many muscle cars BUT I'm looking to sell my daily 
driver (2008 Mustang GT) for a 2013-14 GT with the 5.0.  Since there are so 
many Coyotes on the road now mod prices are dropping.  I plan on adding:
- Full exhaust, long tube ceramic headers, H-pipe, no cats, Borla ATAK 
muffler.  Setup is about $1,200
- Boss 302 intake manifold, throttle body, and cool air intake.  Less than 
$1000
- A 93 octane tune that will (with the previous mods) bring me to about 470 
horsepower at the crank. Good tunes are about $400
- I will either get the 5.0 with the optional 3.73 rear end gear or upgrade 
the default 3.33 to 3.93 to dramatically help the quarter mile time by 
keeping you in the best horsepower range on the tachometer. IF I need to 
upgrade the rear end gear it will be about $800
- Get some 10 inch wide rims (like the GT500) so I can fit very fat, sticky 
tires on the back to help with launch.  I would propably get stock size or 
smaller on the front so it looks like an old school setup.  Maybe $1500? 
Haven't priced these out that extensively.
AND BOOM that's less than $30,000 for a daily driver that would smash 
anyone on the quarter mile.
comments.author: Jimmy Hostetler

comments.text:
+Jimmy Hostetler Yeah some people have this weird idea that no matter what 
American car you buy it will never be as good as a European car. But 
America has produced some truly brilliant cars in that past couples years: 
GT500, GT, Boss 302 LS, 1LE, Z/28, ZL1, ZO6, ZR1, ST, Ford GT, SRT10 ACR, 
CTS-V, Hellcat. I mean a true gearhead won't be able to deny this. If you 
want a BMW because that's what you're in to then go ahead, it doesn't 
bother me. But don't act like a BMW in the same price range as a ZL1 or 
GT500 is going to be as good. BMW's are more expensive, they're luxury cars 
so you'll have to pay a lot more to get something that can compete with 
your relatively cheap sports cars.

I have to agree, I'm pretty sure they got it right with the '14s. I didn't 
like the '15s at first but after seeing a GT350 first hand, they've really 
grown on me. I really like the '12 Camaros, especially the ZL1. I just 
don't like the direction they took them with the current model year. But 
that should all change when the '16s come out, right? I mean like I said 
I'm pretty much a Ford guy but I enjoy all American cars and really any 
solid performance car (European or otherwise). Shoot I wish I was in a 
place to buy a Mustang; I'm currently looking into getting an ST since I'll 
be getting hitched soon and I need something practical.
comments.author: Nickolas Little

comments.text:
+Nickolas Little So true about sending them across the ocean! I know a guy 
that bought a BMW 335i. It was something like $60,000 with a straight 6 
turbo that made 300hp.  If you prefer BMW's for looks or status then by all 
means, please buy one.  But this guy actually thought his car could 
outperform American cars in a similar price range.  A mutual acquaintance 
of ours purchased a 2012 Camaro ZL1.  The funny thing is that those two 
cars cost about the same price (within $2000 sticker) and the BMW 335i's 
specs were nearly identical to a 6 cylinder Camaro or Mustang.  The ZL1 on 
the other hand had about double (580) the horsepower.  When it came to 
performance he was simply embarrassing himself.

Personally I would take any comparable 2011-14 Mustang over a 2011-14 
Camaro, ESPECIALLY the 2013-14 GT500.  That is probably my favorite car of 
all time and sports 80 horsepower over the ZL1 Camaro.  2015 is a different 
story however... I would take a 2015 Camaro 1LE over a 2015 Mustang GT 
Premium.

But I meant what I said about pre-2015 Mustangs, I am actually actively 
looking to purchase a lightly used 2013-14 Mustang GT right now!  They are 
so much more stunning than the 2015 and the price dropped a good amount 
since the 2015 reveal.
comments.author: Jimmy Hostetler

comments.text:
+Jimmy Hostetler The Mustang is undeniably the best sounding American 
muscle car out there. The '14 GT500 was voted the second best sounding car 
in the world (behind the 458 I believe). Yeah some trim levels of the 
Mustang seems to be autozone stickers (Like a Saleen appearance pack or the 
Roush body kit). The Camaro SS is garbage compared to the GT, the 
ZL1/Z28/1LE package is undeniably great. As a Ford guy I have to admit when 
Chevy does a good job. And ditto on the Challenger...that thing needs to do 
some crossfit (I still believe the Hellcat is stunning none the less).

The GT: You are correct on all you points. If I had the money to buy a 2016 
GT, I'd use it to buy a 2006 GT. I'm like you, a GT should have two 
important things: a fun pedal and a V8. I would have liked a reincarnation 
of the GT40 again but oh well, right? I'm with you about it beating 
Ferraris except for their hypercar...I mean that's a tall order to 
accomplish and I'm not sure Ford would be able to do it if they tried....I 
still think they should at least try lol.

The RS: nothing can be said about this car. I'm not worried about it. I've 
experienced an ST first hand and I was blown away with how good it is. The 
RS is just this on steroids so I'm not worried about it (how cool would it 
have been to have another Cosworth though?).

Raptor: I was disappointed to hear it would have a V6. I mean I get they're 
trying to push their whole ecoboost thing but there are some cars that 
don't need it (GT and Raptor). It looks stunning though. 

Taurus: Absolutely. There's no way it can compete against the Charger 
Hellcat or the SS as it stands right now. The SHO used to strike fear in 
the hearts of other sedan drivers, now no one even knows it exists. 

My thoughts on it all? Ford is rolling out fantastic cars but seems to be 
influenced more and more by Europe. I would like to see them build purely 
American inspired cars (with properly mean V8's) and send them across the 
pond to put the pompous Europeans to shame. That's what Shelby did in the 
60's and that should be their goal now.
comments.author: Nickolas Little

comments.text:
+Nickolas Little 
Mustang:
You make good points... I can't argue looks, Mustang wins 8/10 times! Ford 
also wins 10/10 when it comes to engine sound.  And no one can deny the 
Camaro has gotten fat (unless it's sitting next to a Dodge.)  GT350 is nice 
too! I don't like the Mustang Shelby GT though. If your honest it seems to 
be a 5.0 Mustang GT with bolt on parts and a grille that looks like a 
picket fence.  The GT350 is in the same price range and stunning on a whole 
different level.

Ford GT:
Here is the thing though.  It really isn't a Ford GT anymore.  If they 
called it the Ford Probe (or anything else really) I would be singing it's 
praises for being a reasonably priced super car.  The problems:
- Ford GT's have V8's
- Ford GT's are stick shifts (not paddle shifts REAL STICK SHIFTS like a 
Carol Shelby would have done)
- The GT should beat every Ferrari (This one will not be a contender for 
top level exotics like the LaFerrari)
-And lastly (admittedly this one is kind of opinion) it looks way too 
foreign to be a FORD GT!  It borrowed bits and pieces of design from both 
Ferrari and McLauren.  The last one had a much longer time gap and 
maintained a body shape that looked very true to it's heritage.
Overall? Good car, not a GT!

Focus RS:
This will be glorious! As Top Gear stated, it's the return of the Escort 
Cosworth.  AWD with over 300hp is going to put the STi to shame!

Raptor:
6 cylinder? In a truck? Maybe I am old fashioned but nothing will ever 
SOUND as good as a Ford V8.

Fiesta ST:
Amazing performance car that outruns all of the other hatchbacks in it's 
class.

Taurus:
Needs a RWD V8 to keep up with the Chevy SS.

All of the other get normal thumbs up, sorry for the wall of text.
comments.author: Jimmy Hostetler

comments.text:
+Jimmy Hostetler Hot tits that sounds amazing. The 302 LS package of the 
Boss was fantastic so if they did a proper 351....swoon
comments.author: Nickolas Little

comments.text:
+Jimmy Hostetler Yeah I was referring to the 2015 Z/28...I really don't 
want to think about the next installation of the Camaro. I can honestly say 
that I think the Camaro has gotten uglier and uglier. I think the first ZL1 
was stunning (prettiest hood I've seen in a while) but it seems like they 
keep dropping heavier objects on it to get that squished look (and 
halogens? really? If they wanted to save weight they could've gone with 
LEDs). I still think the GT350R will be a solid contender, even for the 
2016 platform. So while the Camaro still might be better around the track, 
Ford is supposed to (or its rumored) drop a new GT500 which will continue 
its streak of being the fastest and most powerful (it should be more than 
the Hellcat). I'll still take a Shelby over a Camaro any day (partly 
because I simply think they look better and partly because I'm still a huge 
fan of Mr. Shelby and everything he did). One problem I have with the 2016 
Camaro is the fact that they're using an already in-use platform. Granted, 
the CTS-V has got to be one of the best american sports cars on the market 
and its really solid, but it would have been nice to see Chevy build a 
brand new platform like Ford did. Though that's just my opinion so there's 
that.

Now the GT....yeah I wasn't too happy at first but I think I know why they 
did what they did. The 2005 GT was meant to pay homage to the GT40. It was 
supposed to look like it, drive like it, and simply be a modern 
reincarnation of the GT40. This new GT is supposed to be a whole different 
beast. Its meant to look ahead and instead of using brute force (like the 
'05 GT) to achieve amazing feats its supposed to use technology. I can't 
say I'm all that happy about it, but the looks have grown on me (those 
wastegates mmmm....) and I'm hoping it has the performance capabilities to 
back it up. All in all, it's a good time to be a Ford fan: Focus ST, Focus 
RS, Fiesta ST, GT350/R, Ford GT, Raptor.....hopefully another fast 
Taurus....soon....?
comments.author: Nickolas Little

comments.text:
+Durham Porsche They should make a Boss 351 with a naturally aspirated 
GT500 motor! That would be so cool, they haven't made a Boss 351 since 1973 
I think...
comments.author: Jimmy Hostetler

comments.text:
+Durham Porsche Being the fastest pony car around a track is a narrow 
market?  Us Americans eat this stuff up man! Good luck driving one mile 
where I live without seeing one. :)  And while most people don't buy the 
race packages (ZL1, Z/28, GT500) having the car with the best reputation 
sells 6 cylinders too!  SO Ford making a nice track edition would be good 
publicity and help ALL Mustang sales.
comments.author: Jimmy Hostetler

comments.text:
Ford has made it very clear that it has no intention to develop a car to 
take on the Z28 - it is far too narrow a market.
comments.author: Durham Porsche

comments.text:
+Nickolas Little  I feel like IF it beats the Z/28 (which is a very 
challenging goal) it might be too little, too late!  The 2016 Camaro is 
rumored to be based on the CTS-V platform and weigh 400 pounds less. 
 Mustang had the strait line advantage due to it reduced weight (and lost 
that advantage in 2015, both being almost identical 0-60 and quarter mile 
times) and now the Camaro may be lighter for the first time since it picked 
production back up in 2010!  I can honestly say that for the first time 
since this start up in 2010, I prefer the Camaro to the Mustang.  I still 
love both, but the Camaro 1LE package got so gorgeous and those taillights 
remind me of the retro Chevy style.  Then mustang gets heavier and hides it 
all behind the independent rear suspension.  Once again, it's a wonderful 
car, but Camaro achieved have taken the upper hand FOR NOW.  My biggest 
problem with Ford is the 2016 GT, the glorious 2003 GT is shaking ti's head 
in shame. But that is a whole different story.
comments.author: Jimmy Hostetler

comments.text:
+Jimmy Hostetler That's what I thought. I'm excited to see what it can do 
and what 3rd parties can do with it. I never would have thought Ford would 
go with a flat-plane crank to be honest. But I guess they're trying to sell 
it to the world now, not just Americans. In my opinion, in order for it to 
be a success it should be able to beat the Z/28. If it can do that then 
I'll be happy
comments.author: Nickolas Little

comments.text:
+Nickolas Little You are correct.  While the Coyote is still in the GT and 
GT Premium the GT350 is using a completely redesigned engine with the flat 
firing crank.  It may have been time for the change, honestly.  The 5.0 is 
based on the block of the 05-10 4.6 motor which is nearly identical on the 
99-02 cobra motor.  Don't get me wrong it is a great motor but the new 5.2 
seems to have a very nice power curve by comparison.  I can't wait to get 
some more numbers when the 5.2 hits the road.
comments.author: Jimmy Hostetler

comments.text:
+Durham Porsche Oh okay, I was just curious because I heard a while ago 
(before the 350 was officially announced) that they weren't using the 
Coyote anymore. The flat plane must be the reason for renaming it. I can't 
wait to see it in action
comments.author: Nickolas Little

comments.text:
you may be right - the flat plane crankshaft makes it into a different 
animal - but they are using the same block, head and cam architecture

comments.text:
I agree - but as a Ford guy I am disappointed that the new Mustang weighs 
so much - we were guaranteed that it would be 400 lbs lighter than the 
Camaro. Secondly, why isn't the suspension as sophisticated as the 
Camaro's? Interestingly the newest Coyote motor, using a flat plane crank, 
and sized at 5.2 liters, will produced 500HP naturally aspirated - sounds 
pretty stout.

comments.text:
Well like it was stated in the video and up top...the zl1 has been de-tuned 
by GM. They're not worried about straight line performance as much as Ford 
is. GM cares about all around performance. 580 crank hp on a performance 
car that can take curves and be dangerous in a straight line as well as go 
get groceries. A damn good tune to put this beast where it should be would 
be perfect numbers for a daily driver. The only problem with the camaro is 
its weight. Course as of now the competition is now in the same a read of 
weight....for now. Gonna be interesting this year when the smaller camaro 
comes out.
comments.author: Clifford Purk

comments.text:
The Chevrolet Camaro ZL1 6.2 is NOT "de-turned". It's still a 6.2L c.i.d., 
however it has different heads than the one on the Corvette. It is more 
powerful than the Corvette, however the Corvette beats it at higher speeds 
and on handling. The ZL1 beats the Camaro in the 1/4 mile but not the 1/2 
mile. Go figure. And Chevy is not going to turn DOWN anything. They want 
anything they produce to be as powerful as possible. The only reason car 
manufacturers used to "de-tune" anything was for it to meet emissions or 
mileage requirements but that is no longer necessary.

upgrades and getting 7+ more psi with the stock heads and making 700+ 
hp...now you sound like a true fanboy. The POINT of this conversation is 
that LS are just as stout as your precious ford heads...case in point again 
I tell you...look at how many people slap turbo on a 5.3 with stock heads 
and run 20 or more psi and the engine runs stout...the cathedral style 
heads that gm uses for the LS engines are stout mother fucker...you need to 
do some research before you come on here trying to sound like the Jeremy 
Clarkson of engines...I dont know near as much as a lot of these guys out 
here on but I do know how stout ford heads are and I damn sure know how 
stout LS heads are...so go troll somewhere else with your shallow info and 
grade school insults. You obviously have no room for facts because you are 
so one track minded and shallow to have respect for other car 
manufacturers.
comments.author: Clifford Purk

comments.text:
+Clifford Purk Dickless: do you have a point with your hotrod motor story? 
I just talked about two road cars. Your not gonna get a closer comparo 
unless you find a 6.2L GT500 or better yet a 5.8L LS9. The GT500 gives up a 
gigantic amount of cubes and still ends up punching the GM motor. Shure 
bitch: turn up the boost on that fucking LS9 for all the good it will do. I 
think you'll need more than 3 psi to break 700 hp. Maybe some fucking 
hotrod heads, you fucking turkey.
comments.author: CJDUBstang

comments.text:
Then explain the LS 4.8 that hot rod magazine has done with stock heads, 
stock rotating assembly, stock lower end and stock fuel system and added a 
turbo system running 26psi making 1200hp makimg 60+ runs on the strip? 
Don't tell me a set of LS heads won't perform just as well you fuckin 
moron. Just because that's what gm runs on forced induction doesn't mean 
the engine and heads can't take it. Do some research...the LS9 in the zr1 
was detuned...look up the facts on that one...the zl1 as well was 
detuned...again...that's a fact...they can run much more boost...just 
because they don't out of factory doesn't mean it's crap....an LS engine 
can handle more boost on stock heads than you think. Don't come on here 
spouting off shit that's on paper that you've looked up on google.
comments.author: Clifford Purk

comments.text:
+Clifford Purk Incorrect. Exhibit A: 5.8L Trinity with 14.0# boost on 2.3L 
TVS SC=662hp (actually the car is closer to 700hp). Exhibit B: 6.2L LS9 
with 10.5# boost on 2.3L TVS SC=638hp. Ford gives up nearly half a litre 
displacement, yet busts at least 40-60 hp more with just 3 psi more? How 
else can it be explained idiot? No a set of LS heads won't "perform as 
well".
comments.author: CJDUBstang

comments.text:
+CJDUBstang yet a set of LS heads will perform just as well...hmmm...go 
figure.

comments.text:
Only GM guys jack off to cfm numbers. Ford DOHC heads flow lower peak cfm,

comments.author: Michael Ellis

comments.text:
+Michael Ellis Can you two stop complaining about which brand you think is 
better? They're both great cars. The Shelby is fantastic at what it does: 
scaring the crap out of you. The ZL1 is great at being a track car. They're 
both really good looking too, even though I prefer the GT500. It's all 
about preference and you can't go wrong with either one of these cars. Plus 
the ZL1 has been dethroned: the Z/28 is much better at going around the 
track. And later this year Ford will have the upper hand when the GT350 and 
GT350R are released. The new Shelby is putting down around 550hp from a 
naturally aspirated, flat-plane crank engine. It's also been built for the 
track unlike the old GT500. So you can fully expect it to spank any Camaro 
on the track. And then, when the next Camaro comes out it might do the same 
thing to the Shelby. That's how it goes with American muscle cars, they 
one-up each other every time a new one comes out.

hop in your 80's corvette and do a sweet one wheel peel for all of us.

comments.text:
+TrulyModernSensation Mopar engines are fine, it's the rest that are junk. 
Historically they can't make a car or truck with electronics that crap out, 
and to that end their electronically controlled automatic transmissions are 
junk. Then there's the front suspensions that are prone to premature wear 
and rust.

has not gotten anywhere near the fail point of Ford or Chevy (especially 
recently, Chevy....)

comments.text:
i have a 2013 gt with the 5.0 and 6 speed, 420 horse at the crank so 
whatever that is at the wheels, thats plenty for me for a daily driver lol. 
But it would be cool to see a 1000 horsepower ford or chevy roll out of a 
showroom

comments.text:
+Sir Jammer yes...the horsepower wars would relive again, and American 
muscle would also start to be respected once more. I'm hoping like you that 
the government stay out this time and let us have our super fast cars.
comments.author: Leonard  Cole

comments.text:
+Leonard Cole personally, I hope the hellcat does well because if it does 
that means Chevy and Ford will have to step up even more. I love horsepower 
wars! back in the 70's I thought the muscle car was dead forever. If the 
damn government keeps their nose out, this could get really good! A 1000hp 
straight out of the showroom???
comments.author: Sir Jammer

comments.text:
I have a 2006 charger srt8 and that car is my everyday work car and the car 
that has to pick up the kids at school, I run her at the local track once a 
month and since 2006 to 2014 the only major work I ever done to her was a 
radiator flush and changed some well burnout tires. I'm a dodge fan of 
course and I'm just trying to state that the dodge hellcat can bring some 
well respected competition!
comments.author: Leonard  Cole

comments.text:
+Leonard Cole like I said....”how long will the Dodge hold together?” we 
already know that you can drive the Chevy and the ford back and forth to 
work everyday and run the crap out of them on the weekend. We don't know 
anything long term about the hellcat.

Make your cars lighter with a tight suspension and you will be

comments.text: Camaaaro? ﻿
comments.author: Bayar Munkhjargal

comments.text:
You want speed get a Mustang you want handling, balance, braking, traction

comments.author: Ernesto

comments.text:
I agree with hartsick. I have a 2012 mustang gt. It's awesome. Handles much 
better than you would think for a live rear axle and the 5.0 coyote engine 
is 412 hp. With a new cold air intake and tune and rear end gears this 
thing is easily a 12 second car. The performance and looks for the price is 
unbeatable. ﻿
comments.author: Victor Caisse

comments.text:
+Kjraider2009 What elevation are you racing at?  What kind of 60-foot times 
are you getting?  Your car should be faster than mid 12's.
comments.author: hartsickdisciple

comments.text:
+Victor Caisse Have a MBRP race exhaust, 4.10 gears, JLT CAI and tune and I 
am sitting at 12.6 in an A6 leaving it in Drive. Have race headers and x 
pipe on the way, hoping with radials and a retune I can get to the low 12s
comments.author: Kjraider2009

comments.text: +Roger Beutler Your car is going to be a monster.
comments.author: hartsickdisciple

comments.text:
+hartsickdisciple About a month ago I had an Edelbrock E-Force Stage II 
supercharger installed on my car. It's supposed to deliver 646 hp thru the 
stock exhaust. However, I don't think the tune that Edelbrock supplied me 
with is worth a shit. I've found a place about 4 miles from home that has 
an engine dyno. My car is going there Monday to get dialed in. I wonder 
what my car could do at the quarter mile once I get the supercharger dialed 
in. My old 69 Mach 1 with a Cobra Jet could only muster 14.30 at our local 
drag strip. It had 4.30 gears. The new stangs are miles ahead of the old 
technology. Have a good one!
comments.author: Roger Beutler

comments.text:
+Victor Caisse I have a 5.0 Coyote Mustang GT as well. Bone stock, 2011-14 
Mustang GT is a mid 12-second car with a decent launch on street tires. I 
did 12.63 and 12.65 on back to back runs on street tires, and my car has a 
3.31 rear end. MGW shifter is the cat's ass.
comments.author: hartsickdisciple

comments.text:
I also have a 2012 GT with an Air Raid Cold Air Induction system, 85mm 
throttle body, Flow Master Catback system, & 3:73 gears.  As it now sits, 
there are very few cars I can't destroy on the street.  I just purchased a 
Boss 302 manifold & a Barton Industries short throw linkage.  The linkage 
on my manual tranny is the only weak point on the car.  Can't wait to get 
these in my car.  I'm from the old school where the car that got from Point 
A to Point B in a straight line won.  And you're right; you can't beat the 
price.  Dollar for dollar the Mustang is the best muscle car, period.
comments.author: Roger Beutler

comments.text: to much power for this guy﻿
comments.author: reon barrett

comments.text: i love american muuuscle car ﻿

The camaro not so much﻿

I would like to see ford bring back the Thunderbird and put it in it's

unless they plan on making another GT they'll be on the competitive world

can't wrap my head around why they haven't gone the way of the sword and 
decided to do battle with GM EVERYWHERE instead of limiting themselves on 
the world stage.﻿
